member.name: T:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.ISettingsTab
member.summary: Represents an individual Settings tab on the Windows Home Server Console Settings page dialog.
member.remarks:
The ISettingsTab interface implements the interface. As such, it implements all the properties and methods of IConsoleTab.
ISettingsTab represents a Settings page tab on the Windows Home Server Console Settings page. Settings tabs can be associated with a particular Console tab. Console tabs are instantiations of the IConsoleTab interface. Console tabs call their associated Settings page tabs by using the property of the ISettingsTab interface.

member.name: T:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IConsoleTab
member.summary: Represents an individual tab on the Windows Home Server Console.
member.remarks: IConsoleTab represents an individual tab on the Windows Home Server Console.

member.name: M:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IConsoleTab.GetHelp
member.summary: Indicates whether or not the default help content for Windows Home Server should be opened.
member.returns: A boolean value that indicates whether custom help content or the default help content for Windows Home Server should be opened when the user clicks the Help button or presses the F1 key. If GetHelp returns true, then custom help content is opened; otherwise, the default help content for Windows Home Server is opened.
member.remarks:
If you choose to provide custom help for your Console tab, use this method to implement how your help content will display and then return true.
Additionally, since the Windows Home Server Console is primarily run on a Windows Home Server client computer through the Windows Home Server Connector, your help content should be implemented so that it can be displayed on a client computer. If necessary, this may require that your help content is installed on Windows Home Server client computers.

member.name: P:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IConsoleTab.SettingsGuid
member.summary: Identifies the GUID of the associated object.
member.value: A System.Guid struct that contains the GUID for the associated ISettingsTab object.
member.remarks: If there is no associated ISettingsTab object, then SettingsGuid should return an empty System.Guid.

member.name: P:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IConsoleTab.TabControl
member.summary: Specifies the control that is displayed on the Console tab pane area.
member.value: An object of type Control that represents the control that displays in the pane area of the console when the user selects a given tab.

member.name: P:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IConsoleTab.TabImage
member.summary: Specifies the image that is displayed on the Console tab above the tab text.
member.value: An object of type Bitmap that specifies the image that is displayed on the console tab.
member.remarks: The Bitmap image must be sized at 32 x 32 pixels.

member.name: P:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IConsoleTab.TabText
member.summary: Specifies the text or caption of the Console tab.
member.value: A string that contains the caption for the Console tab.

member.name: M:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.ISettingsTab.Commit
member.summary: Indicates whether or not settings changes have been committed to backend objects.
member.returns: A boolean value that indicates whether or not settings changes made in the Settings page have been committed to backend objects.
member.remarks:
The Commit method is invoked when the user clicks OK or Apply on the Windows Home Server Settings page.
You should implement the method so that it commits settings changes for your Settings tab to backend objects and then returns true.

member.name: T:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IConsoleServices
member.summary: Represents a set of services that can be accessed from with the Windows Home Server process.
member.remarks: The IConsoleServices interface represents services that can be accessed by Console tab instances from within the Windows Home Server Console process.

member.name: M:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IConsoleServices.EnableSettingsApply
member.summary: Enables the Apply button on a Settings page.
member.remarks: Use the EnableSettingsApply method to enable the Apply button on the Windows Home Server Console.

member.name: M:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IConsoleServices.OpenHelp(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Opens the specified help content file.
member.param: A string that contains the name of the subdirectory under the installation directory where help content is located.
A string that contains the GUID for a specific help topic.
member.remarks: Since the Windows Home Server Console is primarily run on a Windows Home Server client computer through the Windows Home Server Connector, the specified help file must be installed on client computers as well as on the server. The install location on the client computer is %ProgramFiles%\Windows Home Server.

member.name: M:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IConsoleServices.OpenSettings(System.Guid)
member.summary: Opens the specified instance of ISettingsTab.
member.param: A System.Guid struct that contains the GUID of a specific instance of .

member.name: M:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IConsoleServices.OpenUrl(System.String)
member.summary: Opens the specified URL in the default browser on the computer running the Windows Home Server Console.
member.param: A string that contains the URL to open.
member.remarks: When this method is called, the specified URL will open in the default browser on the computer that is running the Windows Home Server Console. In most cases, this will be a Windows Home Server client computer that is running the Windows Home Server Console through the Windows Home Server Connector software.

member.name: T:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IWebGateway
member.summary: Provides an abstract interface for a Web access solution.
member.remarks:
Windows Home Server ships with an installed Web Gateway Provider that is based on Windows Live technology. A Web Gateway Provider is a Dynamic Domain Name System (Dynamic DNS) solution for Windows Home Server. Windows Home Server allows you to develop a custom Web Gateway Provider and then make it available on the Windows Home Server.
To create your Web Gateway Provider, you must create a class named HomeServerWebExtender that implements IWebGateway.
To deploy your Web Gateway Provider, you then include this class in a DLL that follows the naming convention, HomeServerConsoleTab.YourWebAccessSolutionName.dll, where YourWebAccessSolutionName is a name that you use to distinguish your DLL from other HomeServerConsole.*.dll files.
After your Web Gateway Provider has been deployed on the server, users can select which provider to use, configure, edit, and view the status of the Web Gateway Provider through Remote Access on the Windows Home Server Settings dialog.

member.name: M:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IWebGateway.DisableWebGateway
member.summary: Disables the Web Gateway Provider.
member.remarks: This method is called when a user clicks Turn off under Web Site Connectivity on the Remote Access tab of the Windows Home Server Settings dialog.

member.name: M:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IWebGateway.EnableWebGateway
member.summary: Enables the Web Gateway Provider.
member.remarks: This method is called when a user clicks Turn on under Web Site Connectivity on the Remote Access tab of the Windows Home Server Settings dialog.

member.name: M:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IWebGateway.LaunchConfigureWizard
member.summary: Indicates whether or not configuration of the Web Gateway Provider was successful.
member.returns: A bool value that indicates whether or not the Web Gateway Provider was successfully configured.
member.remarks: This method is called when a user clicks Setup on the Remote Access tab on the Windows Home Server Settings dialog. Implement the code to configure your Web Gateway Provider in this method. If the configuration is successful, return true; otherwise, return false.

member.name: M:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IWebGateway.LaunchEditWizard
member.summary: Indicates whether or not settings changes to the Web Gateway Provider were applied successfully.
member.returns: A bool value that indicates whether or not settings changes to the Web Gateway Provider were applied successfully.
member.remarks: This method is called when a user clicks Change on the Remote Access tab on the Windows Home Server Settings dialog. Implement the code to apply settings changes to your Web Gateway Provider in this method. If the settings changes are applied successfully return true; otherwise, return false.

member.name: M:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IWebGateway.LaunchUnconfigureWizard
member.summary: Indicates whether or not the Web Gateway Provider was successfully returned to a non-configured state.
member.returns: A bool value that indicates whether or not the Web Gateway Provider was successfully returned to a non-configured state.
member.remarks: This method is called when a user removes the current configuration from the Web Gateway Provider through the Remote Access tab on the Windows Home Server Settings dialog. Implement the code to remove the current configuration from your Web Gateway Provider in this method. If the Web Gateway Provider is successfully changed to a non-configured state, return true; otherwise, return false.

member.name: M:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IWebGateway.LaunchViewStatusDialog
member.summary: Displays the status dialog for the Web Gateway Provider.
member.remarks: This method is called when the user clicks Details from within the Windows Home Server Settings dialog.

member.name: M:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IWebGateway.QueryWebGatewayStatus(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets the status of the Web Gateway Provider.
member.param: A bool value that indicates whether or not the Web Gateway Provider should return a refreshed status.
member.returns: An enumeration of type that indicates the status of the Web Gateway Provider.
member.remarks: If QueryWebGatewayStatus is called with the refresh argument set to false, the method should return quickly and may return a cached result.

member.name: P:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IWebGateway.GatewayGuid
member.summary: Gets the GUID of the Web Gateway Provider.
member.value: A System.Guid struct that uniquely identifies the Web Gateway Provider.

member.name: P:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IWebGateway.WebGatewayDescription
member.summary: Gets the description of the Web Gateway Provider.
member.value: A string that contains the description of the Web Gateway Provider.
member.remarks: The description of the Web Gateway Provider is displayed on the Select a Domain Name Provider page of the Domain Name Setup wizard.

member.name: P:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IWebGateway.WebGatewayDomainName
member.summary: Gets the domain name for the Web site of the Web Gateway Provider.
member.value: A string that contains the domain name for the Web site of the Web Gateway Provider.
member.remarks: This method should return the domain name that was configured for the Web Gateway Provider and should not contain protocol or port number information.

member.name: P:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IWebGateway.WebGatewayName
member.summary: Gets the name of the Web Gateway Provider.
member.value: A string that contains the name of the Web Gateway Provider.
member.remarks: The Web Gateway Provider name is displayed in Remote Access on the Windows Home Server Settings dialog.

member.name: P:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.IWebGateway.WebGatewayUrl
member.summary: Gets the URL of the Web Gateway Provider.
member.value: A string that contains the URL of the Web Gateway Provider.
member.remarks: The URL of the Web Gateway Provider name is displayed in Remote Access on the Windows Home Server Settings dialog. Note: If the Web Gateway Provider has not been configured by the user, this property will return null.

member.name: T:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.WebStatus
member.summary: Indicates the status of a given Web Gateway Provider.
member.remarks: The method returns a WebStatus enumeration.

member.name: F:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.WebStatus.Working
member.summary: Indicates that the Web Gateway Provider is operating normally.

member.name: F:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.WebStatus.Broken
member.summary: Indicates that a problem has occurred with the Web Gateway Provider that prevents users from reaching the Windows Home Server using the domain name that is configured for their Windows Home Server.

member.name: F:Microsoft.HomeServer.Extensibility.WebStatus.Unknown
member.summary: Indicates that the Web Gateway Provider cannot accurately determine its own state.
